name: The Game of Merry Christmas Goose Chase
description:
Game manufacturers McLoughlin Brothers produced a group of several games, during the late 19th century, called "The Merry Christmas Series." It is likely that the firm marketed these games especially at holiday time, to take advantage of the gift-buying public.

The Game of Merry Christmas Goose Chase is a simple racing game where players try to catch a Christmas goose. This game is targeted toward young children.

name: Sòcc'mel
description:
A trick-taking card game focusing on expressions from Bologna's dialect. Players try to avoid taking suits of unlucky events going around the table by either adding a more powerful event of the same sphere, or trumping the suit with an event of a different sphere (the three spheres being home, work or street). If not avoidable, the trick taking can be mitigated by playing a swear word card, or by a Socc'mel card, which transfer the suit to another player. Goal of the game is pushing the other players anger-meter ("incazzometro") beyond 10 to eliminate them from the game.

The game is marketed for ages 6 up, with the explicit proviso that obscenities from Bologna are widely accepted and not considered offensive (which is the case, to some extent...).

name: Hokuspokus Krötenfuß!
description:
There are 5 different ingredients and the raven cards what count as a jokers in this game.
The object of the game is to collect the most cards in one type of ingredient.

In start each player gets 3 cards and the rest of the cards are placed to 5 pile. Put the frog aside to any pile.

In his turn player rolls the dice to move the frog as many steps as the dice indicates. The player takes top card from that pile.
Now he asks any ingredient from any player and also announces the ingredient he must give back. If that player has the ingredient he must give all cards with this ingredient with the current player. 
Game ends if one of the five piles is exhausted:
The player with the most cards with one type of ingredient is the winner.

name: "Klipp Klapp"
description:
Players take turns dropping their 5 marbles down the channels of the game, trying to get as many marbles as possible down to score at the bottom (hole with different values).

Winner is the first player to exceed 500 points.

Remark:
Published late 1950/early 60's.

name: Subterfuge
description:
Subterfuge is a 2-player, luck-free, abstract strategy game played on a standard chess /checkers board using 12 standard dice (6 each in 2 separate colours).

The game has many similarities to chess but uses d6 dice as the pieces.  Each player starts with their 6 dice in their home territory and they advance into the field to play.  Players alternate moving one of their pieces with the winner being the first player to capture 4 of their opponent’s pieces.

The value of each die face determines the movement and capability of the piece – smaller values move lesser distances but can Capture larger dice – higher value dice move greater distances but Expose smaller dice - equal value dice Influence the value of neighbouring dice, including your own.   Pieces may move forward or backward according to the movement rules defined for each die facing.

Stuterfuge includes many layers of strategic play and brain-burning tactical play, as the dice values change throughout the game.   Game length can vary between 15 to 60 mins, depending on the time permitted for each move.  Multiple variants are also included in the rules, allowing wildly different tactics and play for each game.

name: Millennium Blades
description:
Millennium Blades is a CCG-Simulator -- A game in which you play as a group of friends who play the fictional CCG "Millennium Blades".

In this game you will build decks, play the meta, acquire valuable collections, crack open random boosters, and compete in tournaments for prizes and fame. The game takes you from Starter Deck to Regionals in about 2-3 hours.

Multiple games can also be chained together to form a Campaign, going from Regionals to Nationals in game 2 and from Nationals to Worlds in game 3, with each game introducing ever more powerful cards and higher stakes, but also resetting the power of the game so that each player has a fair chance to win each 'season' of the campaign.

The game draws heavily on Manga/Anime inspiration for its art, and parodies Magic: the Gathering, Yugioh, and many other collectible games.

At its heart, it’s a commodity trading game, except that instead of cubes or stocks, the things you’ll be buying, selling, and speculating on are trading cards that can be used throughout the game in periodic tournaments. By trading wisely, playing the market, working together with friends, building collections, and winning tournaments, you’ll secure points and become the Millennium Blades World Champion.

The game features a system of card pods, where you will play with about 400 of the base game’s 600 cards every game.

name: Kreuz und quer durchs Sachsenland
description:
Objective: be the first to reach the target (Dresden) moving by turns - "Roll and Move" game.

Move forward according die roll along the red line; if you end on a blue marked space follow the blue line until you join the red line again.

Equipment: board, 8 meeples (can be extended), 1 die

Probably published during the 1950's.

name: Знаменитость
description:
"Znamenitost" means Celebrity in Russian. It's a quiz game with a unique mechanic that provides infinite questions, and you don't need a game master to play it.

There are 4 different kinds of decks (24 cards per deck, 96 total).
1. Facts: each card represents a fact from a biography (for example, "She wrote a book", "Something is named after her", "She was imprisoned", etc.).
2. Professions, such as "politician", "actor", "soldier", etc.
3. Alphabet: each card is a letter, which should be the first letter of someone's name, surname, pseudonym, or nick name.
4. Countries, such as "USA", "Germany", or "Russia".

Each round one of the players chooses a deck, reveals the top card and reads its text aloud. Then everybody tries to name a famous person that matches the task of the card. The fastest player reveals the top card of one of the remaining decks, and now the players try to name the person who matches two criteria, and so on.

For example, if the cards "C" and "She wrote a book" were revealed, it's possible to name Julius Caesar, Winston Churchill, Clive Barker, or any other person with the first "C" in his/her name (or surname, or nickname) and known as an author. If nobody could name a person after the next card was revealed, than the player who had correctly named the previous person wins a round. You cannot reveal more than 4 cards (one per deck): if someone has managed to name a person with 4 cards, he wins that round.

The game is played till one of the decks is depleted.

Contents:
96 cards (24 per deck)
2 blank cards for your own tasks
rules

name: Es läuft die Zeit... wir laufen mit!
description:
Two different boards:

1. Uhrenspiel
Objective: move the pawns around the board to the "home" section. Movement is controlled by dice. Learn to read a watch. 
The winner is the first player to move all pawns "home".
Ending on a 'white' space move foreward according to the printed watch, on a 'red' space backwards.
Can be played by 2 persons or 2 teams.

2. Snakes and Ladders

name: Pit of Pillars
description:
Pit of Pillars is an elimination game of placement of men, and moving and capturing stacks. Every capture results in a pillar being erected on the square where the capture took place. Pillars belong to the captor and move as chess queens. They can neither capture nor move over pieces.

Stacks can be split or joined. Whether a stack is vulnerable to capture is determined by the number of adjacent squares. Pillars take away such squares and thus heighten vulnerability of adjacent stacks.

A player wins by eliminating all of the opponent's stacks from the board (regardless of any reserves either player might have in hand) or by leaving his opponent without a legal move. Cooperative cycles are inherently possible, but in regular play the game will seldom end in a draw.

The game can be played using simple generic material: a chess board, draughtsmen, and chess pawns to represent pillars.

name: SEVEN
description:
SEVEN is a tile-stacking game that uses polyhexes of 4 hexagons, called tetrahexes. There are 7 different tetrahexes (hence the name of the game).

Players alternate turns placing one of their tiles according to some simple rules, trying to get the most of their pieces on the topmost layers when the game ends.

The rules also include a variant and some puzzles.

SEVEN is the little brother of Pent-Up, Counterplays and Stack-22.

name: Jaywalkers
description:
Jaywalkers is a two player game, played on the spaces of a 8x8 board.

2 pawns in two colors and 62 path tiles.

SETUP - Place board between players, pawns start on any space of each player’s respective first rows.

PLAY – A player on his turn must take two actions.

1.Place a tile onto an empty space.
2.Move your pawn in a series of one or more rook moves over any number of tiles following any one of three paths shown on a tile you're currently moving over and ending the move on an empty space.

RESTRICTIONS – The tile you placed on your turn must be part of the route your pawn takes. A pawn may not land on a tile. Your pawn may not jump over your opponent's pawn.

ENDGAME – You win if your opponent is unable to take his two actions.

name: Illegal
description:
Description
ILLEGAL is a crazy, offbeat party game for 5 to 9 players where participants each take on the role of an illegal dealer. The game is accessible to casual as well as expert gamers, and has a mature theme. The rules of ILLEGAL are simple, but the game will challenge your skills in negotiation, misdirection, discretion, charisma, and persuasion. The more you play, the more you will learn to expand and master these skills. Each game lasts about half an hour, and is packed with intense exchanges, interactions and a lot of humour.

Launch into this risqué adventure! Dare to become one of these offbeat dealers and get a good laugh with your friends.

How to Play

ILLEGAL is played in two phases:

During the first phase, each player receives a deck of cards prepared by the Game Master (GM). These decks assign each player his dealer role and gives him a good quantity of the corresponding resources. Each player's deck also specifies his buyer role, and he will make every effort during the game to get as many resources as possible of the type he is interested in. These roles are kept secret until the end of the game.

Players leave the table and split up into continually changing pairs or groups to negotiate and exchange some of their resources, away from prying eyes. Every three minutes, they return to the table to collect new resources at the docks (from the GM). Then they go again for another three minutes of secret dealing.

The second phase, called the Tribunal phase, starts once the players have returned to the table and the GM has run out of resources.

At the tribunal, players play the roles of jury members, witnesses, suspects and judges! They openly discuss their suspicions concerning the secret roles assigned to every other player. The GM reveals the suspect cards in pairs representing the dealer and buyer roles assigned to the various players. For each card pair, players have one minute to debate. After one minute, a simultaneous vote is cast, and a suspect is formally accused.

Scoring

At the end of the game, each player reveals his role pair and acquired resources. He scores one victory point for each resource acquired corresponding to his buyer role, one point for each suspect card accusing him wrongly, thus rewarding him for his skills in misdirection and discretion, but he loses 5 points for each suspect card accurately accusing him, representing 5 years spent in prison. It is very easy to end the game with a 10-year jail sentence if you are insufficiently discreet or are too greedy!

name: The Magic Journey
description:
The Magic Journey is a Goose-type game, with players moving via a die roll and obeying the instructions on the illustrated spaces. Whoever reaches HOME first wins.

The Magic Journey was published in a "Tufty" book for children. Tufty games are always about avoiding accidents, and this is no exemption.

name: Danger!
description:
Game featured in the British 1979 Charlie's Angels Annual.

Simple roll and move game for two players. One is the good player representing a member of Charlie's Angels I assume, and the other is the evil player, representing an Enemy Agent.

Players move according to their die roll not forgetting to obey the instructions on special squares, and the first to launch the Rescue Missile (Space 38), wins.

The rules say that the game can be played alone, by 'playing fairly' for the enemy agent's die rolls. It is the first time in a Goose-type game that I have seen a square that only applies to the Charlie's Angel player, who, if she lands on it, she is knocked out of the game. There is no such square for the Enemy Agent so he has a small advantage.

name: A Clear Round?
description:
Game featured in the 1978 Black Beauty Annual.

A simple die rolling game. Each player is a rider in a show-jumping competition. As usual with Goose-type games, there are special spaces (illustrated by a horseshoe). Each special space represents faults earned by the rider that round. These fault points have to be written down as they are earned. A slight twist with this game is that the order of finishing also generates time-faults; 1st to finish, none; second to finish, 5 time-faults, and so on.

After all the players have finished, the player with the fewest faults, wins.

name: Blackberry Time
description:
A game that featured in the British 1975 Disneyland Annual.

A simple roll and move game. Players represent characters from the Disney animated film about Alice in Wonderland.

Roll a 5 to start. When you land on special square they will often tell you how many blackberries you have picked that turn. Record the number so that each player will have a total once all have finished. The player who picks the most, wins.

name: Mickey Mouse's Waiting Game
description:
A game that featured in the British Disneyland Annual for 1977.

A simple Goose-type game. Mickey Mouse wants to go out in his car but his friends want to go with him. He has to wait until one friend arrives (and he looks very cross as he waits by his car). Players move by a die roll and must obey the special squares. The first player to reach square 30, wins.

name: Stellar War
description:
Stellar War is based on an old Avalon Hill card game known as Naval War, but rather than simulate a war at sea during WWII, Stellar War simulates a war in space, in the distant future.

The object is to have the most points at the end of play, by destroying enemy spaceships and space stations and preserving your own. Each player begins with a fleet of ships and stations used to attack opponents, and plays cards from their hand that represent offensive and defensive actions and other special events. Ships and stations can acquire special defenses or abilities. Optional rules are included to allow different configurations of play.

name: Hei Su Hong Su
description:
Hei Su Hong Su is a battle of wits between two opponents, played on an elegantly crafted board framed in genuine cherry or mahogany. Each game includes an authentic Chinese i-ching coin. In Hei Su Hong Su, when tokens are moved off one end of the board, they return on the opposite side. Additionally, unlike other popular strategy games, players are permitted to move neutral and their opponent’s tokens as their own. Hei Su Hong Su is truly a unique and intriguing strategy game.

In Hei Su Hong Su, one player is red, other is black. At the start of the game, each player has nine pieces set up in a square in opposite corners on the board, with 18 white pieces occupying the other two corners. Players take turns “sliding” rows or columns of pieces by removing a piece from an edge and adding it to the other edge. If a player traps a piece by surrounding it with 4 of his color (including “wrapping around” to the other side of the board), it is replaced with with one of that player's pieces. If a player captures and replaces a white piece, the “tug of war” marker moves 1 in his favor on the scale. If a player captures and replaces an opponent’s piece, the marker moves 2 in his favor on the scale. The game ends when the marker has moved all the way to the end of the scale; that player is the winner.

name: Bigfoot
description:
A quick playing card game for two where Bigfoot and the clever Cryptozoologist attempt to outwit each other! Will Bigfoot's hideaways be discovered, leaving him with nowhere to go, or will the Cryptozoologist be left frustrated?

This new game from up and coming designer Scott Almes is the ultimate battle of wits! Depending on what side you're on, you'll be playing a very different game - The Cryptozoologist is laying traps and attempting to trick the Bigfoot who must deduce and work out what's the best option...

One player plays the Cryptozoologist who is hunting for Bigfoot, played by the other player. Each round, the Cryptozoologist will lay out a series of cards in two ‘paths’, which will contain sensing equipment and special actions. Then, Bigfoot must choose which path to go on, triggering any sensing equipment and giving the Cryptozoologist a few more clues about his Lair. The Cryptozoologist wins by pinning Bigfoot in one of his Lairs, while Bigfoot wins by eluding the Cryptozoologist for six rounds. Capturing this beast won't be easy...!

By slowly eliminating the various potential lairs, the Cryptozoologist will slowly whittle down the places where Bigfoot could actually be hiding. However, if this isn't done by the end of the sixth round the beast will escape the clutches of 'science'!

name: Io canto
description:
Each player chooses a pawn and take the 6 pieces of its color.
Put the pawn chosen at the beginning of the board.
Shuffle the 'unexpected' and 'guests' cards in the appropriate spaces on the board.
Shuffle the 24 cards songs and arrange them in the appropriate spaces on the game board.
Insert the jury card inside the bag. If you play in 5 or 6, put them all, or, in the case of 3 or 4 players, only enter the 8 cards numbered from 1 to 2 .
The players alternate in singing receiving the votes of the public (the other players) and the judgment of the jury.
The game is played in 3 rounds plus a final.

Round 1
The current player draws the card song on top of its pile.
Read the songs and decide whether or not to accept the card, otherwise goes to the player to his left until this is chosen by someone.
If all pass, the card is given to the player who had drawn it.
The player who is assigned the card chooses one of the songs written on the front and draws an "unexpected" card.
The player performs the song choice with track on the CD and respecting the rule reported on the "unexpected".
At the end of the performance each of the other players pass a covered card of values.
The player draws a jury card.
The turn passes to the next player. In the first run you must show all at once.
At the end of the performances the players reveal their cards and advance their pawn based on the score received.

Round 2
In the second round the players are performing in duets.
The player chooses a card from the relative number of bunches . Choose a song and a player with which to perform.
The players perform together.
At the end of the performance the other players place a card deck of their color on one area related to one of the two players who have just sung.
Each of the 2-player draws a card and places the jury in your area.
As in the first run will add up your points and advancing the pawn.

Round 3
The last in the standings takes the bunch of songs for the third exhibition and chooses a card based on the type they prefer, without reading the songs.
Then draw a card guest, choose a song and a famous singer and performs alternating a normal singing voice imitation of the chosen guest.
At the end of the performance the other players place a card deck of their color on the area of â€‹â€‹the board on the turn player.

Final
The two players with the highest score in the final play.
The cards not used are shuffled. Players draw a card and perform the song. The other players vote.
Players then draw a card jury.
The player with the highest score is the winner.

name: Rugby Aotearoa
description:
A basic memory-style game with a NZ rugby theme. Collect pairs of cards to score points, play a tackle token to prevent a player from collecting a set.

Released to coincide with the [2013?] Rugby World Cup.

(n.b.: Aotearoa is the Maori name for New Zealand)

name: Bedlam Cards
description:
Bedlam is a humorous card game with some other components, set in an asylum world full of the lunatics from everywhere else in the multiverse.

The aim of Bedlam is to accumulate Heart and Mind points, or be the last player left standing. If a player loses all their Heart points, they are Scared to Death. If they lose all their Mind points, they have Gone Crazy. In either case, they are out of the game.

On a typical turn a player will face an Enemy or Ordeal, and try to beat it using a Slider with inverse stat values to make their Courage and Sanity greater than what they are facing. Beating Enemies and Ordeals earns Reward cards as well as points.

During turns players can place one of each type of Stuff card on the table in front of them. Stuff cards are Weapons, Buddies or Things. Stuff can help its owner, or be used to mess with opponents.

name: Cross Hares: Testing Ground
description:
The first game in the Cross Hares line — each of which will be standalone with its own expansions — is Cross Hares: Testing Ground, a fairly straightforward game in which you want to move down a trail from your starting area in order to "defeat" a factory at the end of the line.

To start, each player chooses one of the six available characters. As you move down the trail, you'll draw cards, which might be good or bad for you, bad for opponents, or terrible for everyone at the table. You'll also acquire useful items and specialties — with each character having a different set of things to find — have adventures, and come into conflict with other players. Conflict in Cross Hares takes the form of either shoving each other back and forth around the map or stealing items.

Don't worry if you're far back on the path away from everyone else as with the right events or die rolls, you can race ahead of the others! Once you get to the factory, though, you'll need all of your skills and items to defeat it, so be sure you save some of your strength for that.

name: Rupert's School-Time Game
description:
Game featured in the 1976 Rupert Annual.

It is a simple roll and move game. Each player chooses a colour and will need 6 counters of that colour. Only one counter for each player will be in play at any time.

Players throw a die to move their way along a 50-space track. If a player lands on one of the six illustrated spaces, they must put their counter on the correct spot for that character. These spots are marked around the illustration in the centre of the board. That player then takes another counter of her colour and starts at square 1 again. Only one of her counters can be on any spot. The first player to have her 6 counters on the spots in the centre, wins.

name: An Invitation to the Mad Hatter's Tea-Party
description:
Game featured in the 1978 British Disneyland Annual. Various Disney characters are illustrated on the board.

This is a Goose-type game. Players move by throw of a die and must follow instructions should they land on one. The first player to reach square 64 by exact throw, wins the game and can enjoy a cup of tea with the Mad Hatter himself.

name: Creative Clash
description:
The graphic design and advertising industry is a fast-paced and competitive place, as any creative or developer can tell you. Creative Clash is a humorous card game that pokes fun at the industry. Players take on the role of owner of their own creative agency. They hire employees, compete to complete projects and buy lots of cool stuff in order to reach their ego goal. The first player to reach their ego goal is the winner. Players have plenty of opportunity to sabotage each other with an assortment of event cards.

It's a quick and casual light card game that typically plays in half an hour.

name: NoGo
description:
Introduction

NoGo is a combinatorial game for two players: Black and White. It's played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square or rectangular board. Board sizes bigger than 9x9 are not recommended. 6x7 boards have been used in some human matches.

NoGo takes the Go concepts of group and liberty and uses them in the most minimalistic possible way. The resulting game, with no captures, no cycles and no scoring, is no rival for Go, but remains a fertile ground for tactical challenges in the Dots and Boxes style.

This game seems to have been first mentioned by someone called John Moore at Sensei's Library, in April 1, 2005.

				
				
					Definitions

A group is a set of orthogonally adjacent, like-colored stones.

A liberty of a group is an empty point orthogonally adjacent to that group.

				
				
					Play

Black plays first, then turns alternate. On his turn, a player must place a stone of his color on an empty point of the board. At the end of a turn, all groups on the board (both friendly and enemy) must have at least one liberty. Otherwise the player's move is illegal. Whoever can't make a move on his turn loses.

name: Game of Tones
description:
Game of Tones is a set of fourteen different music games designed to play with tonalities, chords, measures, key signatures, notes on the pentagram and even the location of the notes on a guitar neck. These multiple games can be played at different levels, depending on the musical knowledge of the players. The deck consists of 52 cards representing musical notes and rhythmic figures, with the help of the Circles of Fifths printed on each card, and with different suits or colors, together with some special wildcards.

It consists of many different games, featuring different game mechanics and goals: getting more points or cards than your opponents, be the first to run out of cards, move cards to certain places on the table, etc. In every game there are two different “levels” to keep track: the Musical Level and the Strategy Level, and both are independent from each other. The Strategy Level depends on the particular game, while the Musical Level can be adjusted in most of the games. Some of the games are up to 10 players, others are solitary type ones, for 2 players, and even some of the games can be played in teams or cooperatively.

Pawns are used in some of the games, and Game of Tones also includes two additional board games. These games are called Pianogram, in which the board represents a G-clef staff or a piano, depending on the orientation in which it is placed; and Fretboard, in which the board represents a guitar (or any other stringed instrument) neck.

Designed from an educational standpoint, Game of Tones includes a list of the musical concepts used in every game, and a teaching guide for music teachers. Game of Tones is not language dependent, except for the instructions, which are available in English and Spanish.

name: Otters
description:
Otters is a quick, kid-friendly card game for 2-4 players ages 6 and up. Players take turns sending otters from their hand to the lake playgrounds on the board, playing 2 cards per turn. If you add enough otters to a playground to fill it up, you win that playground! Whoever has the most valuable collection of playgrounds at the end of the game is the winner.

Most of the game is made up of simple otters numbered 1, 2 or 3. Players must decide which 2 of their cards in hand to play, and which playgrounds to play them to.

There are also special otters in the deck, which players can use to try to win playgrounds quickly, plus alligator cards to keep opponents away from playgrounds.

The playgrounds themselves range in value from 2 to 10, making some easy to win with a card or two, but less valuable to your final score. Others are hard to win but worth lots of points! And if you collect all three playgrounds of the same color, you get bonus points at the end of the game.

Otters is simple enough for kids to play, helping them to learn basic addition. But it's also designed to be interesting for adults, requiring strategic decision making.

Ultimately, Otters is a game about playing with adorable otters with your friends and family.

description:
The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the center section. Movement is controlled by dice. All players move around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to their player's corner and must start their journey over. The winner is the first player to move all pawns to the center space.

name: Bull Moose
description:
Bull Moose is a U. S. presidential election game based on the 1912 election. The split in the Republican party resulted in Teddy Roosevelt launching the Progressive Party. Concurrently the Socialists under Eugene Debs had their best showing to date. The Prohibitionists fielded Eugene Chaffin running only seven years prior to the passing of the 18th Amendment (prohibition). This resulted in a five-way race in which the Democrats actually won and the third party, the Progressives came in second.

The election is represented by a straightforward, card driven, geographically based game where the winners of each state are decided by lot. The winning of the election and victory condition criteria is loosely based on the popular vote and not on how the electoral college actually functions.

name: Downton Abbey: The Board Game
description:
The fast moving game that transports you in to the world of Downton Abbey. As a maid or footman, you have to complete the tasks you are given as quickly as possible. Starting in the Servants' Hall, each player is dealt Destination cards which have varying values indicated by the number of bells on the card. This relates to how important or difficult the task is. The players must then navigate their way around the corridors and stairs of the Abbey, throwing the dice to determine how many moves they can make.

Once they reach the destination of a task, they collect their bell tokens, and the next player throws the dice to set off for the next job. But nothing is that simple! Along the way, a player can land on a 'Carson Card' space and have to take a card, which could either help or hinder them. On other spaces, the player may have to collect a 'Letter' which could call them away from the Abbey, slowing them down or costing them bells! And which route will they take? A short easy looking one to get a job done earning only one bell, or a longer route with the possibility of collecting a higher reward?

The winner is the player who has completed all their jobs and collected the most bells.

name: Shine
description:
Theme - Shine is a biblically based deck building game. In Shine, you are a person who has recently become a Christian. Though saved and forgiven, you still struggle with sin. Your goal is to remove sin from your life and grow in spiritual maturity. To do this, you will spend time in God’s word, prayer, and use your spiritual gifts to minister to the lost and the hurting. It is not as easy as it seems. Satan prowls like a roaring lion. You will face various temptations, but through it all, God will never leave you or forsake you.

Game objective - The object of this game is to build a deck, called a Life Deck. This deck represents a player’s spiritual maturity. Each player starts off with spiritual fruit, and a lot of sin. As the game progresses, players try to remove sin from their life decks and gain various cards, including more spiritual fruit. Character cards that represent people in need and sets of fruit cards are worth victory points.  Sin cards are worth negative victory points. The player, with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.

Game play - As a player you have the choice to pray or to shine.

If you choose to pray, you start off by using one of your spiritual gifts. Spiritual gifts allow a player to gain a specific spiritual fruit card. There are 9 different kinds of fruit cards and they are the resource used in Shine to gain other cards. 
- You may use the abilities on scripture cards that take effect during prayer. 
- You may remove a card from your deck, usually sin. 
- You may also place any number of cards from your hand into your discard pile. 
- To conclude your turn you draw cards until you have 7 cards in your hand.

If you choose to shine, you start by using one of your spiritual gifts. 
- You may play and use the abilities on scripture cards and character cards that you gained during previous rounds. 
- You may trade a fruit card with any card in the fellowship pool. The fellowship pool allows players to trade fruit cards. 
- You may trade in 2 fruit cards to gain a new fruit card. When you trade in a card it is removed from your deck.
- You may play fruit cards to gain new scripture and character cards.
- To conclude your turn draw cards until you have 7 cards in your hand.

When a player draws the last card from their life deck, the current round ends. 
- Each player shuffles their discarded life cards and places them under their life decks.
- Then each player draws the top card of their temptation deck and does what it says. Temptation cards force the player to draw more sin cards and have stronger effects if a player has sin that they have not dealt with.

The game ends when all of the temptation cards have been drawn. Character cards and full sets of 9 fruit cards are worth positive victory points and sin cards are worth negative victory points. The player with the most victory points is considered to be the most spiritually mature and is declared the winner.

name: Fat Zombie
description:
The Zombies have come! Eat your fill of brains to become the fattest zombie. Only then will they call you King!

Fat Zombie is a funny little dice game, a game that melded two of our favorite pastimes: rolling dice and eating. Combined, they form an easy, fun-to-play game about trying to eat as many people as possible to become the fattest zombie! For once you become the fattest zombie... then you shall be King! Why King? Zombies don't care about money, political power or fundraising; they only care about brains. Not even the quality of brain eaten, merely the quantity.

So you and your friends (2-4) set out upon the grandest adventure: to eat as many brains as possible from the hapless humans! But be wary, for the humans are not without the means to defend themselves, and the fattest zombie may soon become the dead undead!

Playing Fat Zombie only takes about twenty minutes, even if you have never played the game. You and your friends are Zombies that wander the streets, looking for delicious brains! On your turn, you draw the top card of the deck and play it for all to see. You will then roll the die to see if you eat the human, if he escapes or hides, or if he kills you.

name: Wolf Chess
description:
As in standard chess, White moves first in Wolf Chess and the winning objective is checkmate, but the game is played on a 10x8 game board that contains a number of special pieces. The king, queen, rook, bishops, and pawns move and capture the same as they do in chess. Special pieces and changes to normal chess rules are as follows:


    The wolf moves and captures as a chess rook or a chess knight.
    The fox moves and captures as a chess bishop or a chess knight.
    The nightrider moves and captures as a chess knight extended to make any number of steps in the same direction and in a straight line.
    The sergeant moves and captures one step straight or diagonally forward. A sergeant can move, like a chess pawn, a double-step straight forward on its first move.
    A pawn (but not a sergeant) may capture an enemy pawn or sergeant en passant.
    Pawns and sergeants promote on the last rank to queen, wolf, fox, rook, bishop, nightrider, or knight. Pawns (but not sergeants) have an additional option of promoting to an elephant; the elephant piece, not present in the starting setup, moves and captures as a chess queen or a nightrider.
    Wolf Chess has no castling.

name: What Are You!?
description:
THE STORY:
You've awakened in an abandoned building with no idea of who you are. There are others with you, also missing their memory. Writings on the wall by those left here before you say that there is no way out, except by being the last. It also says no one here is entirely human, that your true natures will soon begin to reveal themselves. You're not sure about this whole "not human" thing. All you do know is that you plan on being the last one standing, whatever you are!

THE GAME:
What Are You!? is a combat and deduction game where players secretly assume the role of one of ten different monsters. They will then use cards and power up tokens to attack each other while also attempting to uncover their opponents' true natures, and thus their ultimate weaknesses. The player that can outlast the others wins the game and becomes King (or Queen) of all monsters.

name: Shattered Empire
description:
When mankind first discovered warp points, the gravitational anomalies that allowed him to travel to the stars, humanity spread like wildfire. A mighty Empire of Man grew in all directions. Colonies were planted on any planet that could support them. New spacefaring races were encountered, trade established, wars fought. Until finally the Empire of Man grew too large; internal dissention and external jealousy conspired to destroy it. First the far-flung Empire became too difficult to control centrally.  Outer systems demanded more sovereignty, leading to rebellion and civil war. And once that war was lost, neighboring races pounced, snatching what they could. The collapse culminated in the bombardment of Terra and the subjugation of most of the remaining colonies.

Now, years later, humans on Old Terra have finally recovered. Humanity has spread all over known space, but humans on Mother Terra are ready to reach again for the stars. Ready to reclaim their Shattered Empire

Shattered Empire is a Print and Play (PnP) solo game in which the player takes on the struggles of the people of Earth to rebuild and defend their new star empire. The map depicts the systems around Old Terra and, beyond that, the regions controlled by other governments and races. Each turn represents about a decade of time and each ship counter is an individual starship. Players try to expand and defend their empire and score victory points over a 150 year period of time (less if your empire completely succumbs to its foes).

The excact rules of Symmetry are as follows:
-Black and White take turns putting stones on an NxN board (White starts).
-When a stone placing causes a square on the board to be fully covered with stones, this square changes into the color of the last placed stone if the square in question has become horizontally or vertically ´mirror´ symmetric!
-So ´diagonal´ symmetries will not cause any color change.
-Symmetric squares can potentially have any size  (2x2, 3x3, 4x4 etc.)
-Sometimes more than one square becomes a 'symmetry' by a move. All such squares change color.
-The winner is the player who at the end has the most stones of their color on the board!

name: Gladiators
description:
Gladiators is an innovative deck-building game of bloody combat and thrilling gambling. Players use customized decks to play out fast, exciting battles while others bet on the outcome. Winning bets earns you the cash you need to improve your deck.

Players represent gladiators in a Roman arena. Each round they have a chance to buy better weapons, techniques, and armor to help them defeat their foes — with each purchase making a better (and more expensive) version of that card available. Then, they'll challenge one of their opponents to a one-on-one throwdown.

Fights are fast, exciting, and surprisingly tactical. First, players reveal three cards from their deck. Based on this information, all other players bet on the outcome. Players then pick those cards up, draw two more cards, and secretly divide them all into two hands: one hand to be used for its fighting power, the other for the special abilities on the cards. They'll then play out a quick best-of-three combat, simultaneously revealing cards, comparing their powers, and, when necessary, deploying hidden tricks.

When the dust settles, the winning fighter collects a victory chip, and the spectators who bet on him win coins that they can use to improve their decks. Players win the game by besting all of their opponents in combat.

name: L' Audace: The Battle of Abbeville – May 28-29,1940
description:
L'Audace: The Battle of Abbeville: May 28-June 4, 1940,  is a two-player game that simulates the climatic battle of Abbeville.  One player takes on the role of the leader of the counter-attacking French 4th DCR forces, the other the commander of those defending the German bridgehead.

After breaking out of the Ardennes Forest and fighting over the Meuse River at Dinant and Sedan, German mechanized forces raced across France to the Channel, effectively splitting the Allies in two. By the end of May the English announced their intention to withdraw the BEF (British Expeditionary Force) at Dunkirk.  Increasingly desperate, the French high command cobbled together a counter-attack force centered on the newly-formed 4th DCR (Division Char de Reserve), led by General Charles DeGaulle, to retake the channel port of Abbeville.  Victory here against the strung out 57th Bavarian Infantry Division could reunify the Allied forces, and also cut-off the deadly but depleted panzer divisions that had earlier wrought so much havoc.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 40 minutes
Hex: 0.25 miles / 0.40 kilometer
Units: Company

Game Inventory:
Two 11x17" full color maps
One single-side printed un-mounted countersheet (200 1/2" counters)(mounted counters are optional)
One 8-page rulebook
One Player Aid Chart

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Low
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 1.5 to 2 hours

name: Jelly Bean Farmers
description:
Jelly Bean Farmers is a light-hearted game in which you build your farm in a tableau in front of you. You gain food by growing it on your farm or by plundering your opponents as a warlord. Struggle through drought, pestilence, and aggressive neighbors to become the greatest farmer of all time!

The game can be played with 2 to 4 players, but is best with 4.  The game content is appropriate for any age, but the complexity would be a reasonable challenge for a bright seven year old.  Game play is about 45 minutes to an hour, and you will have eaten (usually) 16 of the edible counters when you are done.  (... so don't use large cookies or shots of tequila, but animal crackers or small, disposable cups of beer work fine).

The game lasts for 8 'years,' where each year is split into two seasons.  Each year the players draw cards and choose (in advance) one to play each in the spring and summer seasons.  The players choose whether or not to plant their fields for the spring season, then the spring weather is revealed and players resolve their actions.  There is some flexibility in how a player chooses to resolve the action, especially if he did not plant, but he must use the card that he previously selected for the season.  Crops are calculated and each player must eat one 'food.'  Hopefully he is not eating the last of his seed crop!  Then the planting, weather, action resolution, and crop resolution are repeated for the summer season.  Finally, any warlord tribute is paid before the next year starts.

The game is about 60% luck and 40% skill -- the best players tend to win more often but not every game.  It is silly and fun, with unexpected turnarounds due to odd weather or unexpected cards.  There is also a mechanic where a player who has been wiped out can cash in 'food stamps' and keep playing.

name: Golf 'n' Roll
description:
Golf 'n' Roll is a turn-based board game for 1-4 players that recreates a game of golf,  where players hit balls into a series of holes on a course using the fewest number of strokes. To do this, players must choose the club, decide the strength of the blow... and throw the dice to check where the ball ends!. A typical game lasts between 15-30 minutes, and the minimum age recommended is 5 years old.

Golf 'n' Roll takes place in a rectangular board with 4 golfer tiles, 4 circular numbered ball tokens and 4 dice (white, green, yellow and red).

The holes in the board are divided into squares, where golfers move after hitting the ball. Each of these squares have a gem whose color indicates the difficulty of that trail (green, yellow or red) and a flag indicating the presence or not of obstacles (free, vertical or cross mark). The latest of each hole have a darker green color, an they are called "Green"; one of them which also contains flag is called "Hole."

The game is originally designed for kids and families, so it has a great simplicity, but it also has an "History" gameplay, where our players can acquire skills, which will be very much appreciated for advanced gamers.

name: Naughty? or Nice?
description:
Naughty? Or Nice? is a Christmas themed version of classic party games like Mafia or Werewolf. Great for holiday and family parties.

You can play the game with naughty presents which remove the "elimination" typical of mafia and werewolf games. Or if you prefer the typical werewolf rules, you can use the Krampus cards and kidnap your fellow elves.

This is a social deduction game where players are on naughty and nice teams. At nights, naughty elves break a present. During the days, the nice elves vote on who they think is naughty.

The game ends when one of two conditions are met: 
1.) All naughty elves are exiled and the nice elves win! 
2.) All the nice presents are destroyed and the naughty elves 
win.

name: Martinetti
description:
Martinetti is a type of simple traditional dice game of "climbing" up and down using the results of die rolls. According to game designer and aficionado Dan Glimne it is reputed to date back to Roman times; be that as it may, it could be a precursor to number matching dice games such as Shut the Box

Two or more players can participate, each one writing down a progression of numbers from 1 to 12 and then from 12 back down to 1. On their turn, a player rolls three dice and then crosses off as many numbers as possible, typically in order, by matching them to the numbers on the dice or sums that these add up to. E.g. a first-turn roll of 6-1-1 would allow crossing off the numbers 1 and 2, and a lucky roll of 4-2-1 would mean crossing off every number from 1 to 7. Rerolls may be allowed as long as at least one number was crossed out on the previous roll, except after scoring the first 12.

The first player to reach the end of their sequence, 1 to 12 to 1, is the winner.

Variations concern for instance restrictions on the order in which numbers may be crossed out; restrictions on the use of dice; whether there are two 12 spaces or just one; and whether and how re-rolls are used. If numbers can only be crossed out in strict order, player advancement can be recorded using individual tokens on a single path of numbered spaces.

Similar games include Everest, Mount Everest, Roll and Score Dice Derby Game, and Tolvan

name: Monopoly: Classic Volkswagen Collectors Edition
description:
It's Monopoly for Volkswagen enthusiasts! Same as original Monopoly, with all of the board spaces, cards, tokens, etc. done over with an air cooled Volkswagen theme.

Instead of buying property you are buying classic VW vehicles instead. Houses are now Carports and Hotels are Garages. Road Map and Full Tank cards replace Chance and Community Chest. Gas Stations replace the Train Stations.

Includes 6 collectible pewter tokens: Key, Steering Wheel, Peace Sign, Surfboards (on a roof rack), Gas Can, and a Bud Vase.

name: Weft
description:
Introduction

Weft is a drawless connection game for two players: Red and Blue. It’s played with trapezium-shaped pieces on the cells of an initially empty basket-weave grid. The top and bottom edges of the board are colored red; the left and right edges are colored blue.

All pieces are the same and only differ in color. They can be placed with any side (front or back) up. A cell can accommodate two pieces, and no piece can be placed in a way that makes this physically impossible.

				
				
					Definitions

Two pieces are point adjacent if they share nothing more than a vertex, and edge adjacent if they share at least part of a side longer than a vertex.

				
				
					Play

Starting with Red, the players take turns placing pieces of their own color on empty spaces of the board, one piece per turn.

At the end of a turn, for any two point adjacent, like-colored pieces there must be at least one like-colored piece edge adjacent to both.

Passing is not allowed. Players will always have a placement available and must make one.

The game is won by the player who completes a chain of edge adjacent pieces of their color touching the two opposite board edges of his color. Draws are not possible.

				
				
					Pie rule

The pie rule is used in order to make the game fair. This means that Blue will have the option, on their first turn only, to change sides instead of making a regular move.

name: LEGO Basketball
description:
LEGO Basketball was a subtheme of Sports that ran from 2003 to 2004 with sets and to 2005 with accessories. It was originally licensed by the NBA in 2003, ending the next year. The sets were based on real games, court games, and simple street games.

The minifigures in this theme are known for their special design. They have spring loaded legs and specially designed hands so players can shoot, pass and even reverse slam dunk. It took a team of four LEGO designers and six engineers a full year just to develop the arms and hands so that the minifigures could properly hold, and throw a small basketball piece. They also featured more realistic skin tones, being based on real-life NBA players from real teams.

name: Scrabble Twists & Turns

Scrabble Twists & Turns from Mattel Games takes you off the game grid - you can spell forwards, backwards, up, down - in any which way but wrong! The easy and exciting aim of the game is to get rid of all your tiles first. There's no points awarded, meaning any word can win you the game. A great brain stretcher to share with up to four friends, get your Scrabble Twists & Turns pack today and start twisting your words!

name: Shut Your Mao!
description:
A commercial version of the standard deck playing card game Mao. The game was Kickstartered in 2013, but never released.

The game ran into problems when their Chinese-outsourced printing company explained to them shortly before the end of the Kickstarter that it was "prohibited from printing any images or likeness of Chairman Mao". The designers gave a print-and-play version to backers and went silent, and the game does not appear to have been published beyond that.

name: Tambudschi
description:
Stand up the 3D game board at the end of the table. The players standing at the other side and throw the balls trough the cardboard person's mouth.
Each player in turn throws all the balls, and score each that goes through the mouth on the score board. A certain number of points is set as the limit of the game, and the player who first score that number wins.

name: Tasteless Creative
description:
Hilarious party game with just the right mix of creativity and creation.

Basic Rules
1. To start the game, each player draws a Challenge Card.
2. One randomly chosen player is elected Reader and pulls a Topic Card. The Reader picks a topic
of their choosing from the Topic Card and reads it aloud.
3. All of the other players answer the question on separate pieces of scratch paper abiding by their
Challenge Card and passes it face down to the Reader.
4. While answers are submitted, the Reader should check handwriting so answers have full effect
when read aloud.
5. The Reader shuffles all of the answers and shares each answer with the group, pausing in between
reading each one. The answer with the most laughs wins a point.
6. After the round, a new player becomes the Reader and everyone re­draws a Challenge Card.
7. The player who reaches 10 points first wins. You can alter the win condition to your game
environment.

Topic Cards:
Words...
Creatively define the word given, but don’t worry about coming anywhere close to the real definition!
Just give it whatever meaning strikes you.
Famous People...
Tell us what He or She is famous for...your version anyway. Create an elaborate back story to the
person or tell us a creative tale involving this person.
Movie Titles...
Come up with a terribly clever plot line for the film listed. Is it a documentary? Maybe a hushed noir
film of yesteryear?
Laws...
Fill in the blanks to complete these laws. Your answer can be as long or as short as necessary to
get your point across.

name: Luck O' The Dice
description:
Luck O' The Dice is a game that consists of dice, cards, and coins.  Each player has 6 dice and starts with 5 cards in their hand.  There are two types cards, dice cards and leprechaun cards.  The dice cards have combinations that each player must roll in order to obtain coins, such as 2 pair of a run of 4.  More coins are received if the player rolls dice combinations in one roll instead of having to roll additional times in order to obtain the desired combination.  Upon completing a dice card the player will place this card face up in front of them.  The game ends when any player completes 5 dice cards.  The first player to complete 5 dice cards also gets a bonus which makes it advantageous to complete dice cards the quickest.  The winner of the game is the person with the most coins.

Leprechaun cards allow players to inhibit their opponent's play or to advance their own.  These cards are played at the beginning of a player's turn.  An example is the Slicer card which allows a player to reduce the number of dice a selected opponent can roll on their next turn.  Every leprechaun card relies on the dice, so player's are never assured of their effectiveness.

This game truly revolves around the use of dice and a player's luck can change with just one roll!

name: These French Fries Are Terrible Hot Dogs
description:
These French Fries Are Terrible Hot Dogs is a party card game where players must lie to tell the truth, and convince others that their card is something else, more specifically, cards drawn by other people. Players are encouraged to be clever and to speak with a silver tongue!

During each round of the game, one person will act as the Judge and will take a card from the deck and place it face up. That card is the Target Card. Everyone else then takes a card from their hand and places that card face down. Next, each player must try and convince the Judge that their card is the Target Card by using true information about the card that they just placed down. The act of convincing the Judge is known as The Pitch.

Let's say Bob is the Judge, and he flips over the Target Card "Hot Dogs." Susan then decides to player her "French Fries" card and places it face down. During her pitch, she can say:

“Well, mine's really good plain, but people usually put toppings on it, like ketchup. Others might add chili or cheese. Oh, and you really don't want to eat it cold, it's much better warm."

Once everyone is finished making their pitch, the Judge picks the person who they feel had the best pitch, and declares that person the winner of the round. Players then discard the cards used during that round. Everyone but the Judge and the round winner draws a new card to replace the one that they just played. A new Judge is chosen, and a new round begins.

A winner is determined once a person discards all of their cards and says "These French Fries Are Terrible Hot Dogs!"

name: The Jane Game
description:
The Jane Game is a trivia board game devoted to Jane Austen’s six novels. It is designed to bring Austen admirers together to share in her stories, characters, wit and language. While playing, each participant enters Jane’s world as one of her heroines. As such, you seek after a fortunate life by becoming an accomplished woman, gaining societal experience and choosing to marry or not. Through chance, expertise and choice you could become the envied Mrs. Darcy, the pitied Mrs. Collins or the new roommate of Miss Bates.

The Jane Game is for 2-7 players (Austen wrote seven heroines into her six novels) and lasts about an hour to an hour and a half, depending on how chatty and good-humored the heroines are.

The overall objective is to obtain the greatest Life Fortune. This can be done by trading your accomplishment cards in for something of greater value. The player with the most Life Fortune is the winner.


Designer's Summary:

The Jane Game is a mixture between a role-playing and trivia game. Each player becomes one of Jane Austen’s heroines seeking after a fortunate life. This fortunate life is best achieved by becoming an accomplished lady, a societal woman and by marrying well.

The game has two phases: Courtship and Marriage.
 During the Courtship Phase, turns consist of either answering trivia (there are options of guidance from a governess for those who are not as well versed in Austen’s works) or of acquiring Societal Tokens (Family, Ball, Trip). Trivia answered correctly gives Accomplishment Cards, which are used to acquire Societal Tokens.

The Marriage Phase is quick and starts once the first heroine is married. At this point, each heroine goes to the church where proposals come according to how well trivia is answered. She then can choose her hero (i.e. Mr. Darcy), alternate (i.e. Mr. Collins), or to not marry at all (i.e. become Miss Bates’ new roommate).

Once all heroines have the option to marry or not, Life Fortune Points are counted and the heroine with the most wins.

name: Jane Austen's Matchmaker
description:
In Jane Austen's Matchmaker, a card game for 3 to 6 players, you place your Ladies into Society and propose to other players' Ladies with your Gentlemen. Some proposals lead to love and happiness and some to financial prosperity, but some are nothing more than shallow seductions. Whatever happens, you must ensure that your characters come out on top!

When proposing, if a Gentleman's Charm is lower than the Lady's, he must discard cards to make up the difference. If he wants to really impress her, he can discard additional cards to boost his Charm. If the Lady accepts, the players exchange characters and whoever has the higher Wealth draws cards equal to the difference. If she declines - paying cards if necessary to counter his Charm offensive - the Gentleman returns to the player's hand to brush up on his manners.

Declining a proposal from a Gentleman with a higher Rank will earn you additional cards, and if you have more Ladies in Society than anyone else at the start of your turn, you get an extra 'go'. This can help you to dominate the matchmaking scene but will doubtless draw the ire of your rivals. It's good to be protective of your Ladies, but don't let them get left on the shelf...

When the deck runs out, the game ends and players tally up the Virtue of their married characters, then subtract the Virtue of their 'old maids' (Ladies left unwed in Society). Whoever has the highest Virtue total wins!

name: Jogo Mortal Kombat
description:
THE WORLD’S GREATEST FIGHTERS ARE PRESENT. BUT ONLY ONE WILL BE THE GREAT CHAMPION!
There are 6 character to chose from MORTAL KOMBAT - Shang Tsung, Goro, Jonhy Cage, Rayden, Sonya Blade or
Liu Kang.
Each player chooses one of them and took a position in the arena. Then spins the roulette wheel to move your
character around the arena. The opponent was reached: the battle begins.

Select an hit from the attack cards. Your opponent must defend, counter-attacking with the same hit. The one who
apply the strongest hit - determined by the number of dots - gets to choose the next blow in the combat
sequence and so on. Are always three strokes. The loser, loses a life.

But there’s more: if someone wins 3 consecutive exchanges of blows gets a… “FATALITY”. He has the right to
attempt a fatal blow at the roulette, you can throw the opponent to the throns, eliminating him from the
tournament. Who loses all lives of the same color will also be eliminated. Among all the greatest fighters in the
world, only one - only one - will be the MORTAL KOMBAT’s great champion! Who will be?

name: Mayhem: Fantasy Mass Battles
description:
Mayhem is a ‘fantasy mass battle’ combat game played on the grand scale. Here generals lead armies of their own creation on the field of battle in search of victory and glory.Not just for wargamers, Mayhem is perfect for roleplayers looking to integrate a customizable set of mass combat rules into their campaigns and adventures. The BATTLE CHEST edition includes both the core rules and the STRONGHOLD expansion.

Core rules feature overview:

- custom points based army construction
- uses d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20 dice
- VERSUS game engine [including Deadlocks and Overdrive]
- play at any scale including 6mm, 10mm, 15mm, and 28mm
- players can use armies based for other systems
- no casualty removal
- rule for magic including spells like blink, summon, and time stop
- includes quick reference sheets, army construction worksheet, and General’s Compendium
- official support from popular miniature manufacturers

The MAYHEM core rules give you complete control over building your army from the ground up. After creating core profiles and heroes, you have over 60 options at your disposal that can be used to equip and upgrade. These include unit designations, weapons, armor, standards, traits, abilities, and gear.

The VERSUS game engine layers mechanics and interactions in such a way as to provide a truly innovative and unique gaming experience. To begin with, stats in the game are not based on fixed numbers but on die types instead. Anytime that you are called upon to roll dice, you may instead choose to take the default; this is equal to half the value of the die. This choice of risk versus reward is behind every decision in the game.  These die types can be improved in steps depending on which weapons a unit is equipped with and what type of unit it is combating. This system of soft and hard counters means no complicated tables or stat lines are needed, yet it rewards the application of both tactics and strategy.

The game can be played at any scale, and players may use armies already based for other popular mass battle systems. Speaking of basing, there is no individual casualty removal in the game so hobbyists are free to make each unit a mini diorama. And, after you’ve mastered the basics of battle, the STRONGHOLD expansion awaits!

The STRONGHOLD expansion includes rules for:

- advanced terrain options including the garrisoning, attacking, and burning of structures
- new designations like scout, skirmisher, and heroic skirmisher
- heroes to engage one another in epic challenges
- battle sorcerers that can focus their magical powers to control hulking mechanical constructs or harness the fury of bound behemoths
- new spells, traits, abilities, and gear
- building your own strongholds and keeps including over 15 upgrades to create the ultimate fortress
- siege engines and laying siege to enemy strongholds and keeps
- new scenarios including border keeps and a unique mass battle multiplayer mode
- campaigns and linked games with unit progression, multiple paths to victory, and seasonal weather effects

The expansion has been set-up as a toolbox that will allow you to pick and choose the rules that best fit your group and the gaming experience you’re looking for. It also means that the core rules will grow and evolve along with your tactical and strategic abilities.

name: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County
description:
Join in this crazy dash to hop your frog across the finish line, but don't let your opponent know which frog is yours. Hop. Bluff. Win.

The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County takes place at a frog jumping contest. It relies on bluffing to make your frog finish first, bidding for turn order each round, and planning your next move. At the beginning of the game, each player draws a color card at random to determine which frog to get to the finish line. Cards are used for both bidding for who hops first and the type of action is performed. Actions include hopping one frogs, flipping over frogs, moving to the top of a frogpile and more!

name: A Simplified Wargame
description:
From the beginning of the rules:
"THIS is an attempt to devise a game based on the principles of war—a game, mind you, not a study. There must not be a single umpire about. The rules must cover all questions on what may or may not be done, and decide losses; and yet they must not be too long or too complicated. And the paraphernalia used in the game must be simple."

A Simplified Wargame is an operational level wargame with specific historic theme. Published in Field Artillery Journal (Sept.-Oct. 1922), the game is played on a point-to-point map, drawn up at random by the players, representing a road network. Units secretly allocate military units to a number of forces represented by pins on the map. The contents of each force is hidden from the opponent. Turns are plotted and carried out simultaneously with any battles resolved using bidding mechanics. The goal is to capture the enemy capital.

name: Ars Universalis

Your ability to handle your finances, choose historical figures to support and solve brain teasers will determine your march towards victory!

Players take the role of avid patrons of the arts seeking to gain prestige through their support of the best artists and scientists that history has to offer. At the end of the game, the player who has obtained the highest number of Artistic Prestige points will be crowned the winner!


Ars Universalis es un original juego de mesa para toda la familia en el que interpretas el papel de mecenas del arte, la ciencia y la literatura. Revive el proceso de creación de las obras de ilustres artistas, pensadores y científicos, desde la Edad Media hasta comienzos del siglo XX.

Por medio de un ingenioso sistema de resolución de puzles pondrás a prueba tu percepción y astucia. Enfréntate a sugerentes desafíos, compite por hacerte con los servicios de los más grandes artistas de cada época, gestiona tus recursos y proclámate como el mayor mecenas de todos los tiempos.

name: Desert Island
description:
Washed ashore on a forgotten island with your fellow castaways, you must try to scrape together enough food to survive while avoiding illness, wild boars and deadly tsunami. Hopefully you can keep your secret love alive and help your secret hate find their proper fate.

Desert Island plays in about an hour. Each turn, players take an action and play a fate card that makes an event more likely to happen as well as a target more likely for the event. Actions include foraging for food, scavenging for valuables washed up ashore, and lighting the signal fire. Of course, it might be easier to forage for food in your neighbor's stockpile. Conflicts are resolved by comparing total size on each side of a fight. A random card is added to each side's total.

At the end of the turn, look to see if a boat was sighted and the signal fire lit. If the players aren't yet rescued, Fate will deal a blow to somebody, then everybody must either eat food or take a wound.

Secret love and hate determines victory points.

name: Leijonan Metsästys
description:
Leijonan Metsästys (Lion hunt) is a roll-and-move game set in Finland. Players move on a map of Finland, trying to find the Finnish heraldic lion somewhere in Finland.

In order to examine cities, players must answer trivia questions correctly. Whoever finds the lion, must take it to Helsinki or Ruokolahti. Other players can find "Sisu" tokens and try to reach the goal first in order to win.

The game is designed for the whole family, and features two levels of difficulty in the questions to make the game balanced between adults and children.

name: Rot und grün: Das kleine Verkehrsspiel
description: The players each have a car and a truck. They have to transport building materials and Permits from their starting space to a construction site, where they build houses. On their way, they have to observe the traffic rules. The moves are dertermined by a spinner. Several delivering tours are necessary. The player who finishes his house first, wins the game.

name: 4 Thrones
description:
4 Thrones is a solitaire card game based on a traditional deck of 52 cards. There are four piles (thrones/kingdoms) on which to place all the cards remaining in the deck, one by one. The basic rule of thumb is to place higher cards on lower cards.

The face cards are unique, though, in that they will accept lower cards of certain suits. The Jack accepts a lower card of any suit, the Queen accepts lower cards of hearts or diamonds (love or money, respectively), and the King accepts lower cards that are spades (a soldier's sword).

The game is based on the idea that the four thrones are kingdoms, and you are placing people in power to maintain balance. If you can get through all the cards in the deck successfully, you win.

name: CAPO
description:
CAPO is played with two decks: CAPO cards and Territory cards. CAPO cards represent the city's five mafia families and are numbered from 1 - 10 (#1 being the CAPO) and also contains two Polizia (police) cards. Territory cards depict the city's districts.

The game's objective is to collect 4 Territory cards of the same color. Territory cards can be obtained by winning a round or winning a 'Battle'.

During a round players try to be the first to get rid of their CAPO cards and win a Territory card. Players can get rid of their cards by playing one card, two cards (a duo) or a combination of 4 cards (a CAPO hand).

Some cards have special features. The #9 (Cugine) for instance allows a player to challenge another player for a 'Battle'.

name: States and Statesmen
description:
Tagline:
Educational and Entertaining for All Ages!

Description:
Candidates run for Office in each of the 50 states represented on the Game Board. Each State is delegated a set amount of Electoral Votes. When all 50 states are represented, a National Election is Declared, and the party resident with the MOST Electoral votes is Elected President and declared Winner of the Game!

Contents:
17 1/2" x 18" Board
Six (6) Individual Player Pawns (red, yellow, green, blue, black, white)
Fifty (50) State Cards
Two (2) six-sided Dice
Assorted Candidate Markers (yellow for Congressman, blue for Senator, red for Governor)
Fourteen (14) Political Message Cards
Assorted Monies (Votes) in five increments (500, 1,000, 5,000, 10,000)
Instruction manual

name: Conflicted: The Survival Card Game
description:
Can you handle the decisions you'll face after Doomsday? When civilization and infrastructure are gone, where will you draw the line between your morals and your will to live another day? Most importantly, where will your friends and loved ones who you'll be spending this difficult time with draw the line for themselves?

Conflicted: The Survival Card Game, designed to help you think about life in a post apocalyptic world, lets you explore your own survival philosophy and that of others. On a turn, a player reads the scenario on a card to his neighboring player — for example, Russia, China, North Korea and Venezuela declare war on the United States following the collapse of the dollar — then this player has three minutes to explain how he's respond to this scenario. Everyone else then awards the answering player 0-3 points, either in secret or openly as decided by the group beforehand. Whoever has the most points after an agreed upon number of rounds wins and is deemed best prepper for the end of times.

name: Bobi
description:
Bobi is a new fast paced and addictive game with one very simple goal, to get rid of all your cards before everyone else, because no one likes to lose.

Play in large groups and take it in turn to try and fire through a round with the same colour, but watch out because if you’ve played the highest card and someone else doesn’t have that colour you may be in for a very unpleasant surprise.

Play begins with the roll of a dice to decide the starting colour and after that the player holding the 'Bobi' card of that colour starts the game.  Each player then takes it in turns to play a card of the same colour until each player has played one card to end the turn.

The next turn begins with the player who player the highest card on the last go and continues until players have no cards left in their hand.  However if you don't have a card of the current colour you can play any card you want and force the player who has played the current highest to pick up all the cards in play.

name: Historia
description:
In Historia the player takes control of a realm in the eve of civilization. As ruler you shape the fate of your realm over the course of the centuries, trying with all your might to raise it high above all others. Your goal is to increase the four attributes of your realm, Stability, Power, Culture and Wealth, by taking control of provinces on the map, constructing markets, cities and palaces and playing idea cards that define your form of government, religion, military organization and other aspects of your society.

Each round you are faced with a decisive event in the history of the realm. As ruler it rest upon your shoulders to decide how the situation should be handled. When the peasants rise up in anger for an example, will you soothe their feelings or crush them with an iron fist? An opponent will read the result of your actions in a History book with over 200 paragraphs.

At the end of a game you will have experienced a rich and unique history of your own, whether you won the game or not.


I Historia tar du makten över ett rike som reser sig ur civilisationens vagga. Under århundradenas lopp formar du dess öde, i strävan att resa riket högt över alla andra och så nå ära och odödligt minne. Sätt plogen i obrukat land för att föda din växande befolkning, eller kuva dina grannars undersåtar med erövrarens rätt. Sprid din kultur till andra folk, hungrande efter civilisationens ljus och frukter. Under spelets gång kommer du att inrätta idéer som definierar rikets styrelseskick, religion militär organisation och andra aspekter av samhället.

Varje tur ställs du dock för en avgörande händelse i rikets historia och som makthavare är det på dina axlar ansvaret vilar att fatta beslut om hur situationen skall hanteras. När bönderna gör uppror i vred och oförstånd, skall du då mana till besinning eller krossa resningen i blod? Och vad gör du när riket drabbas av krig, pest eller gudarnas vrede? Resultatet av dina val läses ur en händelsebok med över 200 paragrafer.

I slutet av spelet kommer du att ha upplevt en spännande och unik historia, oavsett som vunnit eller förlorat.

name: Walt Disney's Donald Duck Game
description: This is a trick taking card game with a 40 card deck. The deck is made up of four suits: purple, green, red, and blue. In each suit, some of the cards have duck pictures (Daisy, Donald, Scrooge, etc.). These are the point cards, with their point values shown on each card. The point value is different from these cards' play value, however. By playing cards, players take tricks and try to collect 120 points of point cards to win.

name: Trap the Rat
description:
One player is the rat, trying to move across the board's yellow squares to one of the cheese squares. The other player is the trapper, trying to completely surround and trap the rat.

The rat player moves first, rolling the die and moving from the start square orthogonally that many squares. Then the trapper rolls the die and places that many fences on the board in the slots between squares. There are 5 total fences in the game. Once all fences have been placed, the trapper must use the already placed fences.

The game ends when either the rat cannot move, or the rat reaches a cheese square on the opposite end of the board.

The d6 is missing, so I'm unsure of its marks, but the instructions indicate that it has at least 1 blank spot, and it's reasonable to assume it goes no higher than 3, since a higher roll would be an automatic win for the trapper.

name: Skoklaarg
description: Skoklaarg is a two-player, abstract strategy board game that is played on a 5x9 board. Each player commands one monarch and sixteen minions tasked with capturing the opponent's castle while protecting their own. Opposing pieces line up on both sides of a row of blue squares representing a river. Minions can move one square to any unoccupied space. Monarchs can move one or two squares in any linear direction and are allowed to capture opposing minions that are two squares away. Monarchs can jump over their own minions but cannot jump over an opposing minion unless they capture (sacrifice) their own on the other side. A player wins by moving their monarch onto the opposing castle space from two squares away.

3 rounds. In the first round all players answer questions, making points for a correct answer. In the second round, players face off in pairs. The fastest to book answers the question posed by opponents. Last round the player make a question to his left player, changing player until each player has placed a question. The best two player go to final round made by 10 other questions. The winner will be the player who correctly answers the most questions placed.
